choices.E: Archived redo log files can be multiplexed to a maximum of thirty destinations.
choices.C: Archived redo log files can only be backed up when backing up the database.
choices.D: Archived redo log files get overwritten if the archived redo file destination is full.
choices.B: Inactive redo log groups must be archived before they can be reused.
choices.A: Archived redo log files can only be multiplexed to a maximum of ten local destinations.

comments.content:
I think the 11-31 remote locations are only valid pre-12c. The documentation for 12.1 does not mention this limit:

The LOG_ARCHIVE_DEST_n initialization parameter defines up to 31 (where n = 1, 2, 3, ... 31) destinations, each of which must specify either the LOCATION or the SERVICE attribute to specify where to archive the redo data. All other attributes are optional. Note that whether you are specifying the LOCATION attribute or the SERVICE attribute, it must be the first attribute supplied in the list of attributes.

Destinations LOG_ARCHIVE_DEST_11 through LOG_ARCHIVE_DEST_31 do not support the SYNC, ARCH, LOCATION, MANDATORY, or ALTERNATE attributes, and cannot be specified as the target of the ALTERNATE attribute.

LOG_ARCHIVE_DEST_11 through LOG_ARCHIVE_DEST_31 can only be used when the COMPATIBLE initialization parameter is set to 11.2.0 or higher.

discussion.content:
LOG_ARCHIVE_DEST_n

where:

n is an integer from 1 to 31. Archive destinations 1 to 10 are available for local or remote locations. Archive destinations 11 to 31 are available for remote locations only.

B and E are correct.

A is incorrect. Per 12.1 documentation, log_archive_dest_1 through log_archive_dest_10 must contain either a LOCATION attribute (local) OR a SERVICE attribute (remote.) The question states ONLY local destinations so A can be ruled out. 

E is correct. The log_archive_dest_1 is configured to FRA by default when archive log mode is configured. Leaving a maximum of 30 slots for the MULTIPLEXED copies of the archive logs.

Selected Answer: AB
I think A, B

The Answer is BE
 LOG_ARCHIVE_DEST_1 is always for local destination but the rest 30 LOG_ARCHIVE_DEST are for remote destination like physical standby

discussion.content:
B is the correct answer.
The host naming and the Oracle Easy Connect methods do not require any
client-side configuration files.

questions.question_text: Which naming method enables clients to connect to a database instance without any client side configuration in sqlnet.ora or tnsnames.ora?

choices.A: A newly created job is disabled by default.
choices.E: The CREATE ANY JOB privilege permits a user to create a job in any schema including SYS.
choices.B: A schedule can only be used in the definition of a single job.
choices.F: A job can run only when a scheduler window is open.
choices.D: A program can be invoked by multiple jobs.
choices.C: A job can run without being part of a window or schedule.

questions.question_text: Which three are true about the Oracle Job Scheduler and its components? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
AB 
the tnsping utility. This accepts a connect string and then tests whether it works. It will show the name resolution method used, the Oracle Net configuration files being read, the details of what the string resolves to, and whether there is indeed a listener listening on those details. It does not test whether the database is actually running, but it does attempt to hit the listener and will return a suitable error message if it cannot.

Selected Answer: AB
Answer is AB

questions.question_text:
SALES is a valid TNS entry referring to:

Hostname: HOST01 -

Port: 1521 -

Service_name: SALES_SRV -
You issue this command:
$ tnsping SALES
Which two are true? (Choose two.)

choices.B: It validates that SALES is a valid TNSNAMES entry reachable by the configured name resolution method.
choices.A: It validates that there is a listener on HOST01 port 1521.
choices.C: It validates that SALES_SRV service is active in any database instance on HOST01.
choices.D: It validates that a SALES_SRV database on HOST01 is open.
choices.E: It validates that SALES_SRV service is active in a specific database instance on HOST01.

questions.question_text:
All of your live databases run in ARCHIVELOG mode.
On the SALES database there is no LEVEL 0 backup.
Examine these commands issued against the SALES database target:
RMAN> BACKUP AS BACKUPSET DATABASE;
..
backup set complete, elapsed time: 00:00:03
RMAN> BACKUP INCREMENTAL LEVEL 1 DATABASE;
What is true about the execution of these commands?

discussion.content:
Correct Answer: A

A level 1 incremental backup contains only blocks changed after a previous incre
mental backup. If no level 0 backup exists in either the current or parent database incarnation when you run a level 1 backup, then RMAN makes a level 0 backup automatically.

comments.content:
For C: Wrong
Refer to https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/12.2/bradv/rman-backup-concepts.html#GUID-0E273817-1EE0-40FD-BD92-51C4A0CAAF79
"Incremental backups at level 0 can be either backup sets or image copies, but incremental backups at level 1 can only be backup sets."

For A:
The question doesn't mention whether a level 0 backup exists before "BACKUP INCREMENTAL LEVEL 1 DATABASE;" is executed, so the behavior can be level 0 or 1 backup. A is not fully correct, but considering other options are obviously wrong, A is better than worst.
It memtions that "On the SALES database there is no LEVEL 0 backup."

For D: Wrong
Refer to https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/12.2/bradv/rman-backup-concepts.html#GUID-E9ABBACB-8259-4677-A8D4-81ED3194E7E2
"If no level 0 backup is available in either the current or parent incarnation, then the behavior varies with the compatibility mode setting. If compatibility is >=10.0.0, RMAN copies all blocks that have been changed since the file was created. Otherwise, RMAN generates a level 0 backup."

discussion.content:
For B: Wrong
"BACKUP AS BACKUPSET DATABASE;" is a full backup.
Refer to https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/12.2/bradv/rman-backup-concepts.html#GUID-C93F3588-BBA9-4AE2-9E47-74C7A9468023
"A full backup has no effect on subsequent incremental backups. ...
A full backup cannot be part of an incremental backup strategy; that is, it cannot be the parent for a subsequent incremental backup."
So it's not related to the following incremental backup command.

choices.D: It throws an error because a Level 0 backup does not exist.
choices.B: A backup is created which only contains blocks that have changed since BACKUP AS BACKUPSET command.
choices.C: It throws an error because incremental level 1 backups require image copy backups as the Level 0 backup.
choices.A: A Level 0 backup of the database is created instead of the Level 1.
